bestBHT.bht: To those in doubt, we are called to show mercy and kindness, offering tender affection. For the contentious, we should firmly rebuke them. The fire referred to is not eternal, but rather the present hell caused by their corrupt practices. We are to snatch them from this fire without hesitation, showing compassion through fervent prayer, humble instruction, and genuine concern. Each individual should be treated differently, with the appropriate level of tenderness or severity depending on their circumstances.

Henry Alford: These appear to be the only two meanings of the original word which suit the context.
According to the commonly received text, the rendering will be, as A.V., 'of some have compassion, making a difference,' viz., between them and the others.
The fire is most probably not future eternal fire: but the present hell into which their corrupt doctrines and practices have cast them, not however without reference to its ending in fire eternal.
Albert Barnes: The special feeling to be manifest toward a certain class of persons in seeking their salvation was tender affection and kindness.
The direction then amounts to this, that while we are to seek to save all, we are to adapt ourselves wisely to the character and circumstances of those whom we seek to save.
To be able to do this is one of the highest qualifications to be sought by one who endeavors to save souls, and is indispensable for a good minister of the gospel.
Marvin Vincent: On some have mercy who are in doubt."
The Rev. rendering better suits what follows.
John Calvin: If we wish to consult the well-being of such as go astray, we must consider the character and disposition of every one.
So that they who are meek and tractable may in a kind manner be restored to the right way, as being objects of pity; but if any be perverse, he is to be corrected with more severity.
When there is a danger of fire, we hesitate not to snatch away violently whom we desire to save; for it would not be enough to beckon with the finger, or kindly to stretch forth the hand.
Archibald T. Robertson: Have mercy (ελεατε). Present active imperative of ελεαω (rare form in Romans 9:16 also for the usual ελεεω Matthew 9:27)."
But A C read ελεγχετε, refute, in place of ελεατε.
If the accusative and ελεατε is read, see James 1:6 for the idea (doubters).
John Gill: Compassion is to be shown... by praying with them, and for them, with ardency and affection; instructing them in meekness; giving friendly and brotherly reproofs to them; expressing on all occasions a tender concern for their good; doing them all the good that can be done, both for their souls and bodies.

Compassion should be shown... because God is a God of compassion; Christ is a merciful high priest; a contrary spirit is grieving to the Holy Ghost; saints should consider what they themselves were, and what they now are, and that compassion has been shown to them.
Making a difference between one and another; using some more tenderly, others more severely, as the nature and circumstances of their case appear to be.
John Wesley: Endeavour more deeply to convince of the whole truth as it is in Jesus.
Snatch, with a swift and strong hand, out of the fire of sin and temptation.
On others show compassion in a milder and gentler way; though still with a jealous fear.

bhtAttempts.bht: To those who are in doubt, we are called to show mercy, demonstrating tender affection and kindness. For those who are contentious, rebuke them firmly. The context suggests that the fire mentioned is not future eternal fire, but the present hell into which their corrupt doctrines and practices have cast them. We are to snatch those from the fire with a swift and strong hand, not hesitating to save them, just as we would in a dangerous fire. Compassion should be shown to them by praying with and for them fervently, instructing them meekly, and expressing a tender concern for their well-being. We are to make a difference, treating each person with the appropriate level of tenderness or severity as their case requires.

To those in doubt, we are called to show mercy, kindness, and tender affection. For the contentious, it is important to offer firm rebuke. The fire mentioned is not future eternal fire, but the present hell resulting from their corrupt practices. We must snatch them from this fire, not hesitating to save them. Compassion should be shown through fervent prayer, humble instruction, and genuine concern. Each person should be treated differently, with the appropriate level of tenderness or severity based on their circumstances.

Each individual should be treated differently, with the appropriate level of tenderness or severity depending on their circumstances.
